narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the global energy system; different sources of energy and consumption. We also spent a fair amount talking about NDCs, and looking at how an energy market works.

This was a great class for getting an overview of topics in world energy from a very practical perspective. I learned a lot about the workings of energy grids, the most important modern and future energy sources, how institutions from Yale to the country of China are modifying their energy usage over time, and practical constraints of the global transition from fossil fuels (moving to renewables is a lot harder than it sounds).
Energy markets, carbon capture, nationally determined contributions, social cost of carbon, sector emissions, renewable energy technology + land use
Great class for your first class on energy as it provides a great fundamental understanding of energy and the worlds transition to renewables.
I learned about the global energy transition, energy scenarios, energy usage at Yale, energy usage in other countries, and more.
Vastly increased my knowledge about energy topics as a whole, especially energy markets, land-use of different energy sources, and Sustainable Development Goals.

This was a fantastic overview of current world merry from a variety of standpoints. Fantastic lectures with great guest speakers and group activities. If youre even moderately interested in energy, I definitely recommend taking this class.
I learned a lot about the world energy landscape.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Michael is super knowledgable, it's really great to have a professor who has the answer to every question. Lectures went into a lot of detail but we weren't expected to memorize everything said, but just the overall themes.

Weakness: Because we don't need to know every detail, I felt like I didn't need to pay 100% attention-perhaps just due to my ADHD or Zoom fatigue, but I wish I could've retained more of the knowledge we were being presented.

Strengths: all of the assignments were very interesting, they were all designed to encourage original thought and analysis, which made it a really effective way to learn the material. Professor Oristaglio is also extremely knowledgeable and put a lot of time and effort in the class, which made the whole experience really great!! He is clearly very passionate about the topic as well.

Weaknesses: I dont feel like I got much use out of the readings. There was not a lot of discussion time or place to express our thoughts about them.
Great course.  It would be a little better with a little more of a seminar feel, which I realize was much, much tougher over zoom than if the class was in person.

A strength of this courses as that it allowed me to engage in energy-related topics without the stress of timed exams since our midterm and final were essay-based. I think a weakness was that the topics were very broad and we were not incentivized to retain that information since our midterm/final did not necessarily rely on it.

Well-structured course on a multitude of topics pertaining to energy. The course readings were dense, but that is to be expected given the material. I would have liked to learn more about carbon capture, as this, among other topics was crammed into the last meeting of the course.

Strengths - fun group activities like the electricity market bid. Oristaglio is a great guy, clearly very knowledgeable and always wants to help his students, and pretty low workload. Weaknesses - not a very engaging seminar. Felt more like a lecture and it felt like some of the topics could have been better distributed. For example, we spent many many weeks on the geoscience behind different resources and crammed a lot of important topics and countries together at the end. I thought that we were going to discuss different countries or regions every week based on the original syllabus, but it changed over the semester and we pretty much only spent 2-3 classes discussing a few countries.
This course was extremely well taught and comprehensive. My only wish is that it could meet more often instead of the one lecture a week.
I think the material is very interesting and Prof. Oristaglio is very knowledgeable. I think the course could be made more engaging with more discussions, but it was hard over zoom.

Strengths - you get to know some classmates in energy studies through several group projects; Prof. Oristaglio is always willing to discuss whatever topic is of interest to the class. Weaknesses - some lectures can get pretty slow/dry especially if you already have a general foundation in energy topics, but then again this course is meant to fill in the gaps and be a foundation.  This was also the first time the course was taught I think, so it will probably continue to become more organized.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The only complaint I have about this class is that the class period was very long, and because it was online, it was hard to stay attentive the whole time

Im unsure if this course is meant to be more like a seminar or more like a lecture, but some more opportunities for discussion would be nice. Whether in class, or by introducing discussion post assignments on canvas for students to post their thoughts or questions on the readings & lecture materials
The course was great in the virtual setting, with the only downside being lower student engagement.

I thought the recorded lectures and posted ppts were great. We were given examples for what was expected for the midterm and final and that was helpful. We also were engaged with each other several times throughout the course since we had to made presentations and do an energy bidding scenario. They were some of the most enjoyable times during the class.
This course adapted well to virtual learning - it felt as though we were in person.
Could have had more discussion, more student engagement.
I think needed more emphasis on discussion

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very relaxed but super informative. It was a lot of information to take in but all very relevant and interesting. It was very enjoyable to listen to all the interesting topics and the guest lecturers were absolutely fantastic.
I would certainly recommend it to someone seeking an overview of world energy from a very practical and pragmatic point of view.

Absolutely! It covers the widest array of topics regarding energy that I feel is covered in any energy or environment class at Yale. If you want a survey class to learn more about the energy sector and to determine which youre most interested in, definitely take it. The assignments, such as the energy market bidding assignment, are lots of fun to complete as well
100% yes.  Great for understanding the foundation of energy as well as the worlds transition to green energy.

I think this a good 5th class to take or if you want an introduction into the energy sector and its possible trajectories over the coming decades. I certainly learned a lot since this class goes more in depth than what is talked about during a casual energy-related discourse. I think this class is one of those "you get out what you put into it" classes. Therefore, you can easily pass this class without paying attention in lecture but obviously that would be a complete waste of your time since the topics you could learn about are super important.
For anyone interested in learning more about energy, this is a great course. I also recommend it to energy studies students, as it can be applied to any of the three tracks.

This was the first time this class was being taught, so I'm sure that it will get better in the future. If seminars become a little more engaging with more student discussion, better distribution of energy topics, then yes!
Definitely. This course was extremely interesting and well taught.
Yes, it was great!
